parts.title: The Beginning of Foundation
parts.body: Isaac Asimov's Foundation begins with a young mathematician, Gaal Dornick, traveling to Trantor to meet the legendary figure, Hari Seldon. Set in the vast expanse of the Galactic Empire, the story paints a picture of a society influenced by Seldon's revolutionary science of "psychohistory", capable of predicting vast trends affecting civilizational destinies. Gaal is excited but naive, experiencing space travel's wonders while oblivious to the looming Empire's political tensions. His arrival sets the stage for a tale of ambition, science, and the decay of imperial power.

parts.title: Gaal's Detention and Questioning by Commission
parts.body: Gaal woke up to find himself detained by the Commission of Public Safety at their orders. They questioned him about his connection with Dr. Seldon and the project but Gaal declared his innocence. During the questioning, they disclosed they had been tracking his movements since his arrival, and were aware of Seldon's prediction of Trantor's future, needing to validate it with Gaal. When asked if Seldon had shared a destruction timeline, Gaal confirmed he had but insisted the prediction is mathematical and scientific, not politically motivated.

parts.title: Trial and Purpose of Psychohistory
parts.body: Gaal is on Trantor for the trial of Dr. Seldon, who remains unperturbed despite being the focus of the hearings. The trial is private, focused on Seldon’s prediction of the Empire’s downfall. Seldon argues scientifically that Trantor will be ruined within three centuries due to various social factors. He employs psychohistory, a branch of mathematics that accounts for large human groups, to support his predictions. He stresses the importance of preparing for this by gathering an army of thinkers to compile an "Encyclopedia Galactica." The Commission's Advocate attempts to trap Seldon by questioning the practicable purpose of his project, suggesting insurrection, but Seldon insists the purpose is to "minimize the effects of Trantor's destruction."

parts.title: Seldon's Exile Negotiation
parts.body: Seldon's execution, according to him, would have accelerated the fall of Trantor. He explains to Chief Commissioner Chen that his death now would project a bleak future to the people, leading to political revolutions and trade stagnations. While Chen tries to downplay this as mere frightening words, he proposes an alternative to death: exile to Terminus, a less distracting planet to continue work on the encyclopedia. Seldon muses that such a location has minor disadvantages, but the decision could possibly keep the Empire's peace intact, though it comes with a threat of death if not accepted.

parts.title: Seldon's Revelation of the Real Plan
parts.body: Hari Seldon's holographic message reveals the truth about the Encyclopedia Foundation - it was all a fraud to keep them busy until they had no choice but to continue with a much bigger plan that he had foreseen. The real purpose of this plan was to create a civilizing force to reduce the period of chaos after the Empire's fall from 30,000 years to just 1,000 years. Seldon explains that the path set by his plan has been meticulously calculated using psychology so there is only one path to follow through a series of predicted crises. The current crisis of being an isolated, threatened planet with nuclear resources but no metals was anticipated by Seldon. This particular crisis is deemed straightforward, and he claims the solution is obvious. This was intended to start Terminus off towards becoming a seed for the future Second Galactic Empire. His message declares that the path is marked out for future generations, implying the importance of trust in his plan.

parts.title: Hardin and Verisof Discuss Anacreon Tensions
parts.body: Salvor Hardin and Ambassador Verisof discuss the political situation on Anacreon. Verisof describes the Prince Regent Wienis, who is eager to attack the Foundation. Ancreon discovered a derelict Imperial battle cruiser and wants the Foundation's help to repair it, using refusal as a pretext for war. Hardin plans to defuse the situation by agreeing to repair the ship, showing confidence that Anacreon lacks true capability to harm the Foundation significantly.

parts.title: Tensions and Threats on Anacreon
parts.body: In an exchange between Wienis, the regent, and Hardin, the mayor of Terminus, we see that Wienis is determined to use direct action to force the Foundation to cooperate with Anacreon. Hardin has been taken prisoner and is in a room surrounded by guards. Wienis informs Hardin that Anacreon's navy is heading to attack Terminus, expecting no resistance as they have been armed by the Foundation. However, Hardin reveals his counterstroke: he has ordered every priest on Anacreon to go on strike. This means there is no power outside of the temples, deepening the chaotic situation in Anacreon.

parts.title: Aporat and Wienis's Reluctance and Command
parts.body: Hardin lightly speaks to Wienis, mentioning the hyperwave relay which is about to be demonstrated. The televisor springs to life, drawing Wienis's attention. Theo Aporat, high-ranking priest of Anacreon, feels conflicted over how the ship is being used against the Foundation. Despite his role in its repairs, including installing the hyperwave relay, he is against its use for evil. Prince Lefkin of Wienis dismisses warnings, focusing on the operation of the ship instead.

parts.title: Ponyets' Gold-Making Machine and Askonians' Acceptance
parts.body: Ponyets demonstrated his gold-making machine for the Askonians to gain their favor. Although his sales technique was rough, his device worked, turning iron into gold. When Pherl, a councilor of Askon, expressed doubt about the gold's purity due to its origin, Ponyets cleverly argued that the gold's evil would be nullified when used in the service of ancestors. Despite Pherl's hesitations, the Grand Master was convinced by Ponyets' argument. Ponyets further suggested a thirty-day trial period to assure them of the gold's purity. After some consideration and citing Ponyets' logic, the council agreed. Ponyets proved that a religious perspective could be manipulated to gain a favorable outcome.

parts.title: Mallow's Surprising Demonstration
parts.body: After the tense encounter with a tech-man, Mallow demonstrates the power of his personal force-shield. This device is something the Emperor himself does not possess. By surviving a direct blaster shot, Mallow not only demonstrates its capabilities but also surprises the tech-man, proving the value of his offering. The tech-man was reluctant to cooperate, but this demonstration changes his mind.

parts.title: Mallow's Political Aspirations and Strategies with Jael
parts.body: Mallow is quite relaxed, enjoying a break after long efforts. He discusses his political aims with Ankor Jael, mentioning his plan to gain a council seat. Jael is a former politician with experience, who lost his position to Jorane Sutt, an opponent of Mallow. Jael acknowledges Mallow’s difficulties in becoming a councilman due to prejudice. He emphasizes that Mallow needs to convince the public, which is prejudiced, especially as he is a Smyrnian. Mallow has resources and is determined to pursue his goals. The situation is complex because Sutt, a clever politician, is against him. Mallow relies on wealth and political strategy, including an eventual alliance with Jael to reach his ambitions.
